title: 108_hr989
content: The Act titled "Great Lakes Ecology Protection Act of 2003" requires ballast water treatment regulations. The "Great Lakes Ecology Protection Act of 2003" mandates regulations to prevent the introduction and spread of aquatic nuisance species in the Great Lakes. The Secretary of Transportation must issue regulations to ensure ballast water containing aquatic nuisance species is not discharged into the Great Lakes and to protect the safety of vessels, crew, and passengers. The regulations mandate vessels entering the Great Lakes to discharge or exchange ballast water before entry, use environmentally sound treatment methods, and consider different operating conditions. The regulations for aquatic nuisance species in the Great Lakes require vessels to certify compliance, ensure through sampling and inspections, use scientific information, and not override ballast water discharge laws. The regulations for aquatic nuisance species in the Great Lakes require vessels to certify compliance, ensure through sampling and inspections, use scientific information, and not override ballast water discharge laws. Treatment methods for ballast water tanks are defined as processes to remove or destroy living organisms through filtration, biocides, ultraviolet light, thermal methods, or other approved techniques. The Secretary of Transportation shall maximize public participation in the issuance of regulations required by the amendment made by subsection (a) by publishing an advance notice of proposed rulemaking, making the text available electronically, providing 120 days for public comment, and setting an effective date. The proposed rule includes an effective date not less than 30 days after publication and other means as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. A detailed timetable for implementing treatment methods must be included in the advance notice of proposed rulemaking within 120 days of enactment. The Secretary must issue final regulations within 270 days of enactment for the implementation of treatment methods deemed technologically available and cost-effective. Additionally, regulations for innovative treatment methods must also be developed and implemented. Innovative treatment methods must be implemented within 720 days of the enactment of the Act, as per the regulations established by the Secretary.
